## Review Activity

# Nested Dictionaries

## Nested Dictionaries

- A nested `dict` is just a dictionary inside of another dictionary

outer = {
    "key1": {"inner_key1": "value1", "inner_key2": "value2"},
    "key2": {"inner_key1": "value3", "inner_key2": "value4"}
}

## When to Use Nested Dictionaries

- Whenever one piece of data naturally contains multiple sub-parts

```{python}
students = {
    "Alice": {"quiz": 9, "homework": 10, "final": 8},
    "Ben": {"quiz": 7, "homework": 9, "final": 10}
}
```

## Accessing Nested Items

```python

list = ["eeny", "meeny", "miney", "mo"]
list[0][0]

sentences = [
    ["the", "cat", "sleeps"],
    ["the", "dog", "runs"],
    ["the", "bird", "flies"]
]
sentences[0][0]
```

## Accessing Nested Items

```python
students = {
    "Alice": {"quiz": 9, "homework": 10, "final": 8},
    "Ben": {"quiz": 7, "homework": 9, "final": 10}
}

students["Alice"]["quiz"]
```

## Converting Nested `dict`s to `pd.DataFrame`

```{python}
students = {
    "Alice": {"quiz": 9, "homework": 10, "final": 8},
    "Ben": {"quiz": 7, "homework": 9, "final": 10}
}

rows = []
for outer_k, inner_d in students.items():
    row = {"name": outer_k}
    row.update(inner_d)
    rows.append(row)

df = pd.DataFrame(rows)
df

```
